revision.comment: I edited the page to make description more accurate.
revision.text:
{{Infobox sport | name = Munzee | image = Munzee logo September 2018.svg | imagesize = | caption = | union = | nickname = | first = July 1, 2011
[[Texas]], [[United States]] | registered = | clubs = | contact = | team = *Rob Vardeman - President *Louise Gibson - Global Munzee Events Director *Daniel Fischer - Lead Developer *Daniel Hammock - Player Support Specialist | parent = [[Freeze Tag, Inc.]] | mgender = | category = Outdoor | equipment = [[Mobile phone]] or [[Tablet computer]] with [[GPS receiver]] | venue = [[Earth]] | obsolete = | olympic = | website = [http://www.munzee.com Munzee] }} [[File:WikiMunzee.png|thumb|Illustration of a Munzee, which players create and hide for other players to find]] '''Munzee''' is a [[freemium]] [[scavenger hunt]] game where QR codes have to be found at different places in the real world. The game is similar to [[geocaching]] but uses [[QR code]] technology, in addition to device [[GPS]] location, to prove the find instead of a logbook. Launched in [[Texas]] in 2011, the game caught on first in [[Germany]], along with [[California]] and [[Michigan]]. It is now played in more than 188 countries around the world, and there is at least one physical Munzee deployed on every continent, including [[Antarctica]].{{cite journal|last=Dorsey|first=Erika|title=Member Spotlight|journal=Heartland Highlights|date=2012|url=https://heartlandowners.org/rally/2013/LTA_munzee_hand-out.pdf}} The QR Codes are placed by players at places of interest, The QR Codes are hidden at different places of interest and are often printed on weatherproof stickers. Previously, the places could also be marked by a [[Near field communication|NFC]] tag, however this functionality was removed in 2018.{{cite web|last=Clark|first=Mike|title=Munzee adds NFC to geolocation game|url=http://www.nfcworld.com/2012/09/05/317625/munzee-adds-nfc-to-geolocation-game/|publisher=NFC World|accessdate=28 December 2012}} These stickers are called Munzees. Both the finding and the hiding players receive points for deploying and finding Munzees. The QR codes on the Munzees are read by means of a [[smartphone]] app for [[iOS]] or [[Android (operating system)|Android]]. {{cite news|last=Spencer|first=Susan|url=http://www.telegram.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20121110/NEWS/111109916/1246|title=New game in town|accessdate=28 December 2012|newspaper=Telegram}} The coordinates of the Munzees as well as the data of the players are managed via the central web platform. Virtual Munzees are also available for purchase. These also appear in app lists and on maps, and they are "captured" by locating the app device within 300 feet of the designated location. The device must also be within 300 feet of a QR code Munzee to verify "capture."{{cite web|url=http://speurvuur.nl/site/wat-is-munzee?lang=en |title=About Munzee |publisher=speurvuur.nl |accessdate=2014-01-24}} == History == A common misconception is that the idea for Munzee was inspired by [[geocaching]], a game in which participants search for a hidden cache using GPS technology. However, Munzee co-founder Aaron Benzick (having never been a geocacher) came up with the idea of using QR codes for a game in 2008, but smartphone technology and capability were not available at the time.{{cite news|url=http://www.scntx.com/articles/2011/07/03/plano_star-courier/news/8970.txt|title='M' marks the spot: Locally based Munzee takes hi-tech scavenger hunts global|last=Rush|first=Jessica|date=July 3, 2011 |work=Plano Courier Star|accessdate=28 December 2012}} Benzick, and co-founders, Scott Foster, Chris Pick, and Josh Terkelsen launched the game on July 1, 2011. The term Munzee was derived from the [[German language|German]] word for coin, Münze. Since the domain name munze.com was no longer available, an 'e' was added, which also resulted in what the company felt was a catchy name.[https://munzee.zendesk.com/hc/en-us/articles/211253046 ] The original idea was to use poker chips or rounded coins with QR codes.{{cite news|last=Rush|first=Jessica|title=Resident promotes hi-tech scavenger hunt|url=http://www.littleelmjournal.net/articles/2011/07/13/little_elm_journal/news/9077.txt|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120909232553/http://www.littleelmjournal.net/articles/2011/07/13/little_elm_journal/news/9077.txt|url-status=dead|archive-date=September 9, 2012|accessdate=28 December 2012|newspaper=Little Elm|date=July 13, 2011}} == Munzees == [[File:Munzee.jpg|thumb|Munzee on the back of a traffic sign]] Munzees can consist of any material; they must have at minimum a QR-code and physically meet the conditions of the location (waterproof, weatherproof, etc.). Munzees either can be self-generated and printed or be purchased via the web store or through authorised distributors.{{cite news|last=Brinkman|first=Lillie-Beth|title=Get App-y's odds and ends — Munzee, Pictorama, Flock|url=http://newsok.com/get-app-ys-odds-and-ends-munzee-pictorama-flock/article/3710556?custom_click=rss|accessdate=28 December 2012|newspaper=NewsOK|date=September 18, 2012}} Virtual Munzees can be purchased from the web store.{{cite web|url=http://store.munzee.com/Game-Pieces/ |title=Munzee store |publisher=munzee.com |accessdate=2014-01-24}} To generate or to order Munzees one has to be logged in on the central platform with a unique username. When generating a Munzee, the platform creates a web link, over which the generated Munzee can be managed. This web link is represented as a QR code on the Munzee. A descriptive name and an arbitrarily long comment can be assigned to the Munzee as properties. Both are stored on the central platform (not in the QR code) and can be changed later. After a Munzee is physically created, it can be assigned coordinates anywhere outdoors or indoor and then deployed via the app. Once the Munzee has been deployed it goes live on the map and is ready to be found or "captured" by other players.{{cite web|last=Faulkner|first=Adrian|title=Munzee – A scavenger hunt for your smartphone|url=http://gpstracklog.com/2012/08/munzee-a-scavenger-hunt-for-your-smartphone.html|publisher=GPS Tracklog|accessdate=28 December 2012}} If a Munzee is damaged or taken down, players can report the malfunction and after two reports the Munzee is taken off the map. Additionally, dedicated players in the QRew or ZeeQRew programs are now able to replace damaged munzees with generic stickers. The coordinates of all globally mounted Munzees are managed on the game platform at munzee.com. {{cite web|last=Bourque|first=Andre|title=Driving Kids to Succeed through Gamification|url=http://www.business2community.com/mobile-apps/driving-kids-to-succeed-through-gamification-0281691|publisher=Business 2 Community|accessdate=28 December 2012}} Players navigate themselves to the general location of a Munzee by accessing the map with a smartphone. When they find a Munzee, they capture it by either scanning the QR code or being within a certain radius of the published coordinates. The smartphone app sends the data scanned along with current coordinates to the central system which records the capture. The finder and the player that deployed the Munzee each earn points. The points award to the person who deploys the munzee and who captures the munzee vary depending on the playing piece deployed. == Dissemination == As of August 2019, there are more than 9 million munzees worldwide in 240 countries, and more than 323 million Munzee captures have been recorded. There are also over 400,000 registered users.{{cite web|title=About|url=http://statzee.munzee.com/|accessdate=July 19, 2016}} == References == == External links == * [http://www.munzee.com Munzee web platform] [[Category:Outdoor locating games]] [[Category:2011 establishments in Texas]] [[Category:Navigation]] [[Category:Hobbies]] [[Category:Internet object tracking]] [[Category:Near Field Communications]]
